column2: We will allow the Latinois into $COUNTRY$, so long as they cause no trouble.
They bring dangerous ideas. $COUNTRY$ will refuse them all access.

One of our coastal provinces is bustling with rumors about the strange people who were found along its shorelines earlier this morning. The more precise origin of these shipwrecked sailors is as of yet uncertain, but, wherever they are from, they are definitely not from $COUNTRY$. The difficulty now lies in deciding what to do with them: if we send them home, we are effectively changing our policy of non-interaction with the Latinois. Ignoring them and allowing them to stay, however, means permitting a Latinoi presence in $COUNTRY$ despite all our efforts.

One of our subjects has been discovered wearing Latinoi clothes, and further interrogation by the authorities has lead to the slow unraveling of a Latinoi smuggling ring. These foreigners come into $COUNTRY$ without permission, knowing they face execution should they be caught-- yet some of our advisors say there are benefits to their presence, as they can supply needs to the $COUNTRY_ADJ$ people that we cannot.
Shut it down and confiscate the contraband.
In what should come as no surprise, the Latinoi smuggling ring in one of our provinces has been caught red-handed selling opium to the locals.
Do whatever it takes to eliminate this menace.

An old pond
A frog jumps in �
The sound of water.'

-- Matsuo Basho

$PROVINCENAME$ ist voller Ger�chte �ber die seltsamen Menschen, die heute Morgen am Gestade gefunden wurden. Die genaue Herkunft dieser schiffbr�chigen Matrosen ist noch unklar, aber woher sie auch stammen m�gen, sie sind definitiv nicht $COUNTRY_ADJ$.

column2: Round them up and execute them.

We have received reports that a number of our missionaries have been executed in $FROMCOUNTRY$, part of a $FROMCOUNTRY_ADJ$ action to round up all unwanted foreigners. The missionaries were peaceful, and the $COUNTRY_ADJ$ public is understandably enraged. Many believe that war is necessary, while others believe the potential for war with $FROMCOUNTRY$ simply isn't worth it. The missionaries knew they were not permitted in $FROMCOUNTRY$, after all.
There is nothing we can do.

News reaches us that an expatriate community of foreigners, from various Latinoioi countries and Great Powers, has formed in one of our cities. Doubtlessly, this is a direct effect of our government's policy of open ports and borders. This influx might be positive, as our government seems to believe, however some voices have less kind things to say about the foreigners.

A group of $COUNTRY_ADJ$ citizens who left $COUNTRY$ some time ago on an expedition to $FROMCOUNTRY$ has been viciously refused entry to the country. It appears that the $FROMCOUNTRY_ADJ$ government has turned gradually to a policy of increasing isolationism, most likely in order to avoid the pains of modernizing their political, economical and social institutions. This policy of the $FROMCOUNTRY_ADJ$ government is, obviously, impairing the advances of $COUNTRY_ADJ$ trade, diplomacy and missionary activities in the region, and must be considered an unjust restriction of the international freedom of movement.
Force of arms must be considered.
We must respect and tolerate the differences between our respective cultures.

Despite the obvious rightness of our country's trade policies, greater amounts of Latinoi goods could be useful, and elements within our administration have suggested setting up a limited trading post in one of our coastal cities, where Latinoi ships can moor and trade, without compromising the cultural integrity of $COUNTRYNAME$. It could be an economic boon to the area and the nation, but conservative voices warn that destructive Latinoi influences might further creep into our society.
column4: Trotz der offensichtlichen Richtigkeit unserer Isolationspolitik k�nnte eine gewisse Menge ausl�ndischer G�ter uns von Nutzen sein. Einige Elements in unserer Regierung haben vorgeschladen, einen beschr�nkten Handelsposten in $PROVINCENAME$ zu errichten, wo ausl�ndische Schiffe ankern und handeln k�nnen, ohne im Gro�en und Ganzen unsere Politik der Separation vom Rest der Welt au�erhalb $COUNTRYNAME$ zu kompromittieren. Es k�nnte f�r das Gebiet wie auch die Nation einen wirtschaftlichen Aufschwung bedeuten, aber konservative Stimmen warnen, dass destruktive ausl�ndische Einfl�sse sich in unsere Gesellschaft einschleichen k�nnten.

column2: Keep it small. Keep it simple. Keep it under control.
column3: Voir petit. Faire simple. Maintenir sous contr�le.
column4: Immer sch�n klein halten. Immer sch�n simpel halten. Immer sch�n unter Kontrolle halten.

column2: A sweet, pungent stench hangs over the backstreets and alleys in one of our cities, emanating and spreading in every direction from an epicenter at the Latinoi trade station. The Latinoioi traders have brought with them the habit of opium smoking, and our subjects have taken to it on a scale that threatens to become epidemic. It seems that, for every new ship that lands, more and more of our people get caught in the deadly and pacifying web of addiction. What should we do?

Die europ�ischen H�ndler haben die Gewohnheit des Opiumrauchens mit sich gebracht, und unsere Untertanen haben sie auf eine Stufe erh�ht, die zu einer Epidemie zu werden droht. Es scheint, dass mit jedem neuen Schiff, das ankert, mehr und mehr unserer Untertanen sich im t�dlichen Netz der Sucht verstricken. Was sollen wir tun?

column2: It is not our place to intervene
column3: Ce n'est pas notre r�le d'intervenir.
column4: Es ist nicht unsere Pflicht, zu intervenieren.

column2: Issue an edict banning the sale of opium
column3: Signer un d�cret interdisant la vente d'opium
column4: Edikt erlassen, das den Opiumverkauf verbietet.

column2: Due to the trade restrictions on the sale of opium, a number of Latinoi merchants have instead gone underground. We have word that a group of them have set up shop in one of our coastal provinces, but so far none of the locals seem willing to come forth with information. If we allow the smuggling ring to remain, it seems only a matter of time before the opium problem spreads.
Do whatever it takes to uproot them.

The great clippers ply our coastlines from north to south, like wolves culling out the weak and the corruptible with the poison they sell. Wherever there is an unexposed harbor, a Latinoi ship soon docks, and drives another fang into our national body. The use of opium has spread to $PROVINCENAME$.
column4: Die gro�en Klipper fahren unsere K�ste von Norden nach S�den ab, wie W�lfe, die sich die Schw�chsten aus der Herde suchen - in diesem Fall die mit ihrem wohlfeilen Gift Korrumpierbaren. Wo immer sich ein neuer Hafen findet, ankert bald ein ausl�ndisches Schiff und rammt einen weiteren Rei�zahn in den K�rper unserer Nation. Der Opiumgebrauch hat sich nach $PROVINCENAME$ ausgebreitet.

column2: Order local officials to destroy opium shipments
column3: Ordonner aux autorit�s locales de d�truire les cargaisons d'opium

column2: The use of opium in a neighboring province has now spread to the inland. Farmers and laborers in $PROVINCENAME$ fail to turn up for work, and entire fields fall fallow, as the people of $PROVINCENAME$ slip further and further down into the mists of consuming dependence.
column4: Der Gebrauch von Opium in einer Nachbarprovinz hat sich nun ins Inland ausgebreitet. Bauern und Arbeiter in $PROVINCENAME$ erscheinen nicht mehr zur Arbeit, und komplette Felder liegen brach, als die Menschen in $PROVINCENAME$ tiefer und tiefer in den Nebel der verzehrenden Sucht sinken.

column2: It is not our place to intervene

column2: The use of opium in a neighboring province has now spread to the inland. Farmers and laborers throughout $STATENAME$ fail to turn up for work, and entire fields fall fallow, as the people slip further and further down into the mists of consuming dependence.

column2: We find that your country is sixty or seventy thousand li from $COUNTRY$. Yet there are barbarian ships that strive to come here for trade for the purpose of making a great profit. The wealth of $COUNTRY$ is used to profit the barbarians. By what right do they then in return use the poisonous drug to injure the $COUNTRY_ADJ$ people?'\n\nOne of our governors has taken the opium problem into his own hands, and written a letter to a Latinoi head of state, questioning the morality of their support of the opium trade.
column4: Wir sehen, dass Ihr Land 60- oder 70000 Li von $COUNTRY$ entfernt ist. Trotzdem kommen die Schiffe der Barbaren hier, um zu handeln und gro�e Profite zu machen. Die Barbaren profitieren vom Reichtum von $COUNTRY$. Mit welchem Recht schaden sie denn dann mit ihrer giftigen Droge den $COUNTRY_ADJ$ Menschen?'\n\nEiner unserer Gouverneure hat das Opiumproblem in seine eigenen H�nde genommen und einen Brief an ein ausl�ndisches Staatsoberhaupt geschrieben, in dem er die moralische Basis des Opiumhandels kritisiert.

column2: No! Apologize and stop this nonsense!
column3: Non ! Pr�senter nos excuses et arr�ter ces b�tises !
column4: Nein. Entschuldigen und mit diesem Unsinn aufh�ren!

column2: Rangaku', literally translated as 'Dutch learning', and by extension 'Latinoi learning', is a Japanese word used to describe a particular body of knowledge and learning imported from the west via a Dutch trading station at Dejima. Something similar has ocurred at the trading station in one of our provinces, where local officials are busy transLatinoig Latinoi books and treatises on science, advancing $COUNTRY_ADJ$ science and understanding of the world.
column4: Rangaku', w�rtlich �bersetzt als 'Lehren der Holl�nder', und weitergehend als 'Lehren aus dem Westen', ist ein japanisches Wort, das ein bestimmtes Wissen bedeutet, welches aus dem Westen �ber einen holl�ndische Handelsposten in Dejima nach Japan kam. Etwas �hnliches ist am Handelsposten in $PROVINCENAME$ geschehen, wo �rtliche Beamte damit besch�ftigt sind, westliche B�cher und wissenschaftliche Abhandlungen zu �bersetzen, um die $COUNTRY_ADJ$ Wissenschaft und die Kenntnis von der Welt weiterzubringen.

column2: He hides his face and speaks with controlled anger. A local aristocrat has been insulted by one of the foreigners living in one of our provinces. Apperantly, the foreigner in question failed to bow in the appropriate manner when passing the aristocrat on the street. Shall we tolerate such blatant ignorance of our customs?

Offensichtlich vers�umte der Ausl�nder, sich in der korrekten Weise zu verbeugen, als er dem Aristokraten auf der Stra�e begegnete. Sollen wir solch blatante Ignoranz unserer Sitten tolerieren?

column2: The foreigner is ignorant, not malevolent
column4: Der Ausl�nder ist ignorant, nicht b�sartig.

column2: Perhaps some gold could make things better?
column3: Un peu d'or rem�dierait peut-�tre au probl�me ?

column2: He unveils the device with the excitement of a child. - 'You can see their eyes!', he cries, pointing excitedly at the jar of beetles. He instructs you to look into the object -- the glass and metal is cold against your face -- there, in curves of an optic lense, reality is magnified ten times over. - 'It's a microscope!, he laughs. - 'I bought it from one of the foreigners!'
column4: Er enth�llt den Apparat mit der Begeisterung eines Kindes. - 'Man kann ihre Augen sehen!', ruft er aus und deutet aufgeregt auf das Glas mit den K�fern. Er bedeutet Ihnen, in den Apparat zu schauen -- das Glas und Metall f�hlt sich auf Ihrem Gesicht kalt an -- dort, in den Biegungen einer optischen Linse, sieht die Realit�t zehnmal gr��er aus. - 'Es ist ein Mikroskop!', lacht er. - 'Ich habe es von den Ausl�ndern in $PROVINCENAME$ gekauft!'

column2: The foreigners have gone too far! Their missionaries spread false teachings, subverting our people and our national unity, they break our customs, and their opium clouds our minds. At least that is the message you will get if you ask the people in $PROVINCENAME$ where anti-Latinoi sentiments have been running high for the past months.
column3: Les �trangers ont d�pass� les bornes ! Leurs missionnaires enseignent des contrev�rit�s, subvertissent notre population et notre unit� nationale
column4: Die Ausl�nder sind zu weit gegangen! Ihre Missionare verbreiten falsche Lehren, unterwandern unsere Bev�lkerung und nationale Einheit, sie brechen unsere Gebr�uche und ihre Opiumschwaden vernebeln unseren Verstand. So lautet jedenfalls die allgemeine Meinung, wenn man die Menschen in $PROVINCENAME$ fragt, wo die Stimmung gegen Ausl�nder in den letzten Monaten sehr hoch ist.

column2: We have decided to open our doors to the West, and if we expect our subjects to embrace this policy, it becomes important that we ourselves, the Royal family, set good examples. Well educated leaders will be absolutely essential if we are to fully take our rightful place in the court of nations, and by sending our progeny abroad for education in Europe, or by hiring Latinois to educate them here, we can accomplish just that. What say you, your majesty?
column4: Wir haben uns entschieden, unsere T�ren dem Westen zu �ffnen, und wenn wir von unseren Untertanen das Gleiche erwarten, ist es wichtig, dass wir selbst, die k�nigliche Familie, mit gutem Beispiel vorangehen. Gebildete F�hrer werden von �u�erster Wichtigkeit sein, wenn wir unseren rechtm��igen Platz am Hof der Nationen einnehmen wollen, und das erreichen wir, wenn wir unsere Spr��linge auf europ�ische Schulen schicken oder Westler einstellen, um sie hier auszubilden. Was sagt Ihr dazu, Eure Majest�t?

column2: The Latinoioi governess we have hired to educate the court seems to be doing fairly well at her job, but she has been introducing some rather strange ideas around the place. For instance, she has been throwing around, in quite harsh language, the idea that all men are created equal, and that $COUNTRY$ should abolish the time-honored institution of slavery. I don't know, your majesty, this sounds like dangerous stuff...
column4: Die europ�ische Gouvernante, die wir zur Fortbildung des Hofes eingestellt haben, scheint ihren Job recht gut zu tun, aber sie hat auch einige recht merkw�rdige Ideen mitgebracht. So bestand sie zum Beispiel darauf, und in recht harschen Worten, dass alle Menschen gleich sind und $COUNTRY$ die altehrw�rdige Institution der Sklaverei abschaffen sollte. Ich wei� nicht, Eure Majest�t, das h�rt sich gef�hrlich an ...

column2: Enjoy the conversations, but ultimately do nothing
column4: Die Gespr�che genie�en, aber nichts tun.

column2: Dangerous or not, I believe she is right

column4: Gef�hrlich oder nicht, ich denke, sie hat Recht.

column2: Some intelligence concerning our military preparations has spread from the military mission in one of our provinces, severely hurting our war effort. We have expelled the members of the mission, but the damage has already been done.

column2: The high militancy among certain parts of the population in $PROVINCENAME$ has lead to an outbreak of violence directed at local expatriate foreigners. The embassies of the Great Powers have all lodged formal diplomatic complaints with our government, and seem to expect some sort of action on our part. What should we do?

Die Botschaften der Gro�m�chte haben alle formelle diplomatische Beschwerden an unsere Regierung gerichtet und scheinen von uns Handlungen zu erwarten. Was sollen wir tun?

column2: What shall we do with the drunken sailor?
column4: What shall we do with the drunken sailor?

column2: Sailors winding up drunk in $COUNTRY_ADJ$ prisons aren't normally affairs of state, but this is an exception. A navyman from one of the Great Powers has been arrested by officials in one of our cities, after having murdered one of our subjects in what appears to have started as a bar fight. The diplomatic attach� insists that the sailor be handed over to the country in question, and tried according to their laws. This presents us with a conundrum. Granting this privilege once is tantamount to allowing extraterritoriality to all Latinoi subjects, but not doing so might very well cause international uproar. This issue merits careful consideration.
column4: Betrunkene Matrosen, die in $COUNTRY_ADJ$ Gef�ngnissen landen, sind �blicherweise keine Staatsaff�ren, aber dies ist eine Ausnahme. Ein Matrose aus einer der Gro�m�chte wurde in $PROVINCENAME$ verhaftet, nachdem er einen unserer Untertanen im Verlauf einer Kneipenschl�gerei umbrachte. Der diplomatische Attach� besteht darauf, dass der Matrose den Gerichten seines Heimatlandes ausgeliefert und dort nach ihren Gesetzen verurteilt wird. Dies bringt uns in eine Zwickm�hle. Dieses Privileg ist ein wichtiger Teil der Extraterritorialit�t, die allen Ausl�ndern zusteht, aber wenn wir es nicht tun, sehen wir einem internationalen Aufschrei entgegen. Dieses Problem muss sorgf�ltig durchdacht werden.

column2: Hand him over to the foreigners

A depesch has arrived from our attach� in $FROMCOUNTRY$, detailing the tragedy of a sailor in our merchant marine. Apperantly, the sailor killed a local in a scuffle during an extended shore leave in $FROMPROVINCE$. Despite pressures from our diplomatic mission, he was later tried and executed according to $FROMCOUNTRY_ADJ$ laws. While we mourn his passing, we should also take some time to consider what we should do about this grave and serious insult to our national honor.
column4: Eine Depesche ist von unserem Attach� in $FROMCOUNTRY$ eingetroffen, die von der Trag�die eines Matrosen unserer Handelsmarine berichtet. Trotz Druck aus unserer diplomatischen Mission wurde er sp�ter gem�� den $FROMCOUNTRY_ADJ$ Gesetzen vor Gericht gestellt und hingerichtet. W�hrend wir um den Verstorbenen trauern, sollten wir uns zugleich Gedanken um diese schwere und ernsthafte Beleidigung unserer nationalen Ehre machen.

column3: Boire le calice jusqu'� la lie

column2: News reaches us from $FROMCOUNTRY$ that they have decided to allow foreigners to be tried according to the laws of their native countries. Doubtlessly caused by pressure from within the circles of the Great Powers, these are good news nevertheless.
column3: Nous venons d'apprendre que $FROMCOUNTRY$ avait d�cid� d'autoriser les �trangers � �tre jug�s selon les lois de leur pays d'origine. Nous devons sans nul doute cette bonne nouvelle aux pressions exerc�es par les grandes puissances.

column2: A group of Latinoi expatriates currently residing in $CAPITAL$ have offered an invitation to high-ranking members of the $COUNTRY_ADJ$ government to attend a fancy affair in the Latinoi quarter. We're well aware that this is just an excuse for these men to gain more influence in $COUNTRY$-- but there could be benefits for us as well, namely using the opportunity to gain insight into their methods.
Refuse. We don't need their methods.

A group of $COUNTRY_ADJ$ entrepeneurs recently spent time plying $FROMCOUNTRY_ADJ$ officials with liquor and favors at a formal affair in $FROMCOUNTRY$'s Latinoi quarter. The result is promising-- a number of new business ventures and trade deals, giving $COUNTRY$ greater sway over $FROMCOUNTRY_ADJ$ affairs. All these men require is our government's support.
They have our permission to continue, but we can offer no support.
This is not in our best interest.

With the Latinoioi presence in our part of the world steadily increasing, the need for military reform becomes more dire every day. Where the Latinoi field regiments of drilled professionals, we meet them with an army that is old and outdated, and organised along the lines of clan, family, nobility and personal loyalties.
column4: Mit steigender europ�ischer Pr�senz in unserem Teil der Welt wird das Bed�rfnis nach Milit�rreformen t�glich dringender. Die Europ�er haben Regimenter gut gedrillter Professioneller, und wir stellen ihnen eine Armee gegen�ber, die altmodisch ist und nach Clans, Familien, Adel und pers�nlicher Loyalit�t organisiert.

column2: We will not abandon our traditional ways
column3: Nous ne renoncerons pas � nos traditions.
column4: Wir werden unsere Traditionen nicht aufgeben.

column2: We have suffered a defeat. Despite our policy of splendid isolation, a hostile world has made inroads into ours. $SPHEREMASTER$ has forced our country open, and the gravitation of their might and power has brought our political life into orbit around theirs. Latinoi traders, missionaries and spies pour across our borders, all the while undermining our traditional sovereignty over this, our homeland. No longer the masters of our own fate, our first priority now is to obey. But some dark night...
column4: Wir haben eine Niederlage eingesteckt. Trotz unserer Isolationspolitik hat eine feindliche Welt ihren Weg in die unsere gefunden. $SPHEREMASTER$ hat unser Land zur �ffnung gezwungen, und die Schwerkraft ihrer Macht hat unser politisches Leben in die Umlaufbahn um ihres gebracht. Ausl�ndische H�ndler, Missionare und Spione ergie�en sich �ber unsere Grenzen und unterminieren unsere traditionelle Hoheitsgewalt �ber unser Heimatland. Wir sind nicht l�nger die Herren unseres eigenen Schicksals, und unsere erste Priorit�t ist es, zu gehorchen. Doch in irgendeiner dunklen Nacht ...
Wir warten auf den richtigen Zeitpunkt.

column2: News reaches us from $FROMCOUNTRY$ that the local ruling elites have thrown our ambassador out of the country, and that their troops are laying siege to our embassy with apparent intent to enforce that decision. This affair is developing into an enormous loss of international face, one which can only be avoided through a formal declaration of war against $FROMCOUNTRY$. Sire, how should we respond?
column3: Nous venons d'apprendre que les �lites locales de $FROMCOUNTRY$ ont expuls� notre ambassadeur et que leurs troupes assi�gent notre ambassade. Cette affaire s'av�re lourde de cons�quences aux yeux du monde et il nous faut reprendre les choses en mains en d�clarant la guerre � $FROMCOUNTRY$. Monsieur, que devons-nous faire ?
column4: Uns erreichen Nachrichten aus $FROMCOUNTRY$, dass die lokale Herrscherelite unseren Botschafter des Landes verwiesen hat, und dass ihre Truppen unsere Botschaft anscheinend mit der Absicht belagern, diese Entscheidung auch durchzusetzen. Diese Aff�re bedeutet f�r uns einen gewaltigen internationalen Gesichtsverlust, auf den wir nur mit einer formalen Kriegserkl�rung an $FROMCOUNTRY$ reagieren k�nnen. Wir sollen wir handeln?

column2: Perhaps we should let the $FROMCOUNTRY_ADJ$ Dragon sleep.
column3: Nous devrions peut-�tre laisser le dragon $FROMCOUNTRY_ADJ$ dormir.
column4: Vielleicht sollten wir den $FROMCOUNTRY_ADJ$ Drachen schlafen lassen.

column2: Our relations with $FROMCOUNTRY$ have worsened to the point that members of their government have begun a campaign to reduce or even eliminate $COUNTRY_ADJ$ influence. Some of our diplomats have fled, and now we are faced with the unpleasant prospect of either enforcing our interests or suffering embarassment at our inability to manage a former ally.
We will not go to war over this.

So shall ye not only be Our good and faithful subjects, but render illustrious the best traditions of your forefathers.'\n\n$COUNTRYNAME$'s educational system is deeply mired in ancient tradition and long-established dogma. While it has helped maintain the traditional order in eras past, the old system has a hard time integrating the new knowledge that is spreading from the civilized nations of the west. By reforming the system we risk upsetting the vested interests of the traditionalists, but can we afford not to?
column4: Ihr sollt nicht nur unsere guten und treuen Untertanen sein, sondern auch die besten Traditionen eurer Vorv�ter am Leben halten.'\n\nDas Bildungssystem von $COUNTRYNAME$ steckt tief im Sumpf uralter Traditionen und etablierter Dogmen. column2: Several of the Great Powers have in the past few years sought to establish formalized and permanent embassies in $COUNTRYNAME$, but up until now we've turned down their proposals. However, an idea has been floating around the capital that we should perhaps allow them to set up these embasasies after all, provided they are all kept in one place where we can exact some amount of control over them. Perhaps a Latinoi Quarter in $CAPITAL$ could be just the thing?

column2: Wandering alone in the streets of $CAPITAL$ can be a dangerous thing, as a Latinoi ambassador in the Latinoi Quarter recently found out. Guards report having found him dead at 4 a.m. in the morning, apperently the vicitm of a robbery, however the foreigners accuse us of having failed in our supposed responsibility to protect their diplomats. We fear that even a formal apology will not be enough to placate them, however, something more tangible might...

column2: The oil lamp flickered, casting an orange, sooty glow across the moist brown of the cargo hold. The average ship docking in $PROVINCENAME$ carried very little to raise an eyebrow, but years of being fooled and fooled again by Latinoi merchants, trying to dodge some excise or other, had left him with a sixth sense for when things were out of order. A rat scurrying between some crates tipped him off. A sweet, pungent scent too familiar not to be alluring. Opium. A cargo hold full of opium.

column2: One of our traders was turned away from the port in $FROMPROVINCE$ some time ago. Apperantly he was discovered by local customs officials trying to smuggle opium, despite the $FROMCOUNTRY_ADJ$ ban on opium imports. A liberal politician in our lower house has addressed the matter.\n\n'The right to trade freely, and openly, across the seas and on land, is one of the unalienable rights of mankind. Our rights have been denied in $FROMCOUNTRY$, and I for one wonder how long the government will stand for these slights at the hands of uncivilized heathens.

Unsere Rechte wurden uns in $FROMCOUNTRY$ verweigert, und ich m�chte wirklich wissen, wie lange die Regierung diesen Schm�hungen unzivilisierter Heiden noch unt�tig gegen�berstehen will.

column2: Your trading restrictions are a disgrace to the world, and to yourself. Loyal $FROMCOUNTRY_ADJ$ subjects, merely wishing to see their rights of trade upheld, have been turned away from your ports, and we request that this slight be immediately undone. $COUNTRYNAME$ will cease this infraction, or prepare itself to face the consequences.

column2: The trade disputes between $FROMCOUNTRY$ and the Great Powers had been on-going since the latter half of the 18th century. Tensions finally escalated to the boiling point in $MONTH$ of $YEAR$, when $FROMCOUNTRY_ADJ$ officials had repeatedly turned down $COUNTRY_ADJ$ requests for unlimited trade access, including a lifting of the ban on the sale of opium. The $COUNTRY_ADJ$ government, already deeply invested in a policy of confrontation, found itself with no options but to declare war, thus, the $COUNTRY_ADJ$-$FROMCOUNTRY_ADJ$ Opium War begun.

Die $COUNTRY_ADJ$ Regierung, die schon viel in eine Politik der Konfrontation investiert hatte, sah sich gezwungen, den Krieg zu erkl�ren, und so begann der $COUNTRY_ADJ$-$FROMCOUNTRY_ADJ$ Opiumkrieg.
